questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He has had multiple falls while walking and running for the past 4 months. He used to be able to climb stairs independently but now requires assistance. He started speaking in 2-word sentences at 2 years of age. He is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Examination shows a waddling gait and enlargement of bilateral calves. Muscle strength is decreased in the bilateral lower extremities. Patellar and ankle reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. To rise from a sitting position, he uses his hands to support himself to an upright position. Diagnosis is confirmed by a muscle biopsy and immunohistochemistry. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the most severe clinical presentation of this disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A same sense mutation produces no clinically apparent changes, because it does not entail any changes in the encoded protein. For the majority of amino acids, there is more than one codon (genetic redundancy). In the case of the dystrophin gene, same sense mutations would cause no manifestation of the disease.

B) INCORRECT:

A silent mutation produces no clinically apparent changes, because it does not entail any changes in the encoded protein. For the majority of amino acids, there is more than one codon (genetic redundancy). In the case of the dystrophin gene, silent mutations would be most likely to cause no manifestation of the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

A missense mutation is a possible, though rare, cause of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The dystrophin gene is the longest in the entire genome with many exons and introns. As a result, missense mutations may not become clinically apparent unless they occur in particularly sensitive regions of the genes, such as those that code for binding sites for other proteins. They may also result in a more mild presentation (Becker muscular dystrophy).

D) INCORRECT:

Splice site mutations have a variable effect on phenotype. Mutations at the splice sites can lead to abnormal exclusion of an exon, producing a peptide that lacks the amino acids of that single exon. The location of the exon is crucial to predicting the severity of the mutation; some exons are inframe, in which case their absence will very likely lead to an otherwise normal sequence peptide. Other exons may be out of frame, leading to an abnormal sequence of amino acids and a truncated protein. Severe splice site mutations may result in Duchenne muscular dystrophy if they result in completely dysfunctional dystrophin; if the protein retains some function, it causes Becker muscular dystrophy.

E) CORRECT:

A frameshift mutation often has very severe phenotypic consequences because they result in significant changes in the entire nucleotide code of the remaining gene, and therefore, lead to major changes in the expressed gene's structure and function. Frameshift mutations may also result in premature stop codons that would cause an abnormal interruption of the translation. The dystrophin gene is the largest identified gene in humans and a frameshift mutation will likely cause dystrophin not to be able to even minimally function as a linking protein in muscle cells, giving rise to the severe phenotypes of Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

Isolated nonsense mutations are also associated with more severe phenotypic manifestations. A key difference between an abnormal stop codons of a frameshift mutation and those of a nonsense mutation is that those of a nonsense mutations will allow for completely normal amino acid sequences before the stop codon whereas frameshift mutations will usually lead to abnormal amino acids before the pathological stop codon.
questions.hint: Gower sign is highly suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. In genetic diseases, the type of mutation determines the severity of the disease. Certain types of mutations are associated with mild manifestations, while others can take on very severe forms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for genetic counseling. Her brother and maternal uncle both have anemia that worsens after taking certain medications. Based on the pedigree shown, what is the probability that her son will be affected by the disease?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The pedigree analysis confirms an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern in this woman's family and shows that her mother must be a carrier of the defective X chromosome (since the woman's brother is affected). There is a 50% chance that the woman is a carrier and a further 50% chance that she passes on the mutated chromosome to her unborn son. Therefore, her son has an overall 25% risk of inheriting G6PD deficiency (0.5 x 0.5 = 0.25).

B) INCORRECT:

There would be a 0% risk of the woman's child develop X-linked recessive G6PD deficiency if the woman was not a carrier or the child were female (since she would receive a normal paternal X chromosome). The pedigree analysis of this woman indicates that the mother of the woman must be a carrier (i.e., for the woman's brother to be affected). Therefore, there is a 50% chance that the woman is a carrier. Accordingly, the risk of the son developing G6PD deficiency must be greater than 0%.

C) INCORRECT:

If the mother were affected by G6PD deficiency (i.e., if she had two mutated X chromosomes), there would be a 100% chance of the son developing the condition. Given the pedigree analysis, which confirms an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, her mother must be a carrier of a mutated X chromosome. However, since it is unknown whether the mother inherited the condition, i.e., there is only a 50% chance that the woman is a carrier, her son cannot have a 100% chance of developing G6PD deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

This woman's child would have a 12.5% chance of developing G6PD deficiency if the sex was unknown. The pedigree analysis confirms an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern in this woman's family and shows that her mother must be a carrier of the defective X chromosome (since the woman's brother is affected). There is a 50% chance that the woman is a carrier, further 50% chance that she passes on the mutated chromosome to her child, and a 50% chance that her child will be a boy. Therefore, her child has an overall 12.5% risk of inheriting the G6PD deficiency (0.5 x 0.5 x 0.5= 0.125).

E) INCORRECT:

If the woman is a known carrier of the mutated X chromosome (e.g., if her father were affected), her son has a 50% chance of developing G6PD deficiency. However, based on the pedigree analysis and her family history, which indicate an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, the patient's mother must be a carrier of the mutated X chromosome. Since the woman has a 50% chance of being carrier, her son cannot have the same probability of having the G6PD deficiency.
questions.hint: Inherited anemia that develops in response to medication (typically strong oxidants) is consistent with glucose G6PD deficiency, which is an X-linked recessive disorder.

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-month history of progressive listlessness. His mother says, "He used to crawl around, but now he can't even keep himself upright. He seems so weak!" Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Examination shows hypotonia and an increased startle response. Genetic analysis show insertion of four bases (TATC) into exon 11. Further evaluation shows decreased activity of hexosaminidase A. Which of the following mutations best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A frameshift mutation is caused by the insertion or deletion of a number of nucleotide bases that is not divisible by 3 into/from a segment of DNA. This results in complete misreading of information downstream of the insertion/deletion because of disruption of the triplet structure of codons. In this case, frameshift mutation results in decreased protein translation of hexosaminidase A causing deficiency of this enzyme. Tay-Sachs disease classically causes progressive neurodegeneration, developmental delay, a red spot on macula, and lysosomes filled with GM2 ganglioside.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is also caused by a frameshift mutation.

B) INCORRECT:

A missense mutation is caused by a nucleotide base change in DNA that alters protein translation; the mutated base triplet encodes a different amino acid (e.g., AAG → AGG, which causes a change from lysine → arginine) without causing premature termination of protein translation (i.e., the new codon is not a stop codon). Missense mutation is not caused by the addition of bases into a DNA sequence.

C) INCORRECT:

A nonsense mutation is caused by a nucleotide base change in DNA that creates a stop codon that prematurely terminates protein translation (e.g., AAG → UAG, which causes a change from lysine → stop codon) and results in the production of a truncated protein. This mutation is not caused by the addition of bases into a DNA sequence.

D) INCORRECT:

A silent mutation is caused by a nucleotide base change in DNA that does not alter protein translation because the mutated nucleotide base triplet (codon) encodes the same amino acid. This most frequently occurs when a nucleotide base changes in the third position of a codon (e.g., AAG → AAT; both codons encode lysine). This redundancy of the genetic code facilitates stable translation of functional protein even when there are minor mutations. Silent mutation is not caused by the addition of bases into a DNA sequence.

E) INCORRECT:

A splice site mutation is caused by change, insertion, or deletion of nucleotide bases at the end of introns that result in the retention of introns or the erroneous splicing-out of exons at the level of messenger RNA processing. This patient's mutation is within exon 11 and per definition cannot be a splice site mutation.
questions.hint: This 8-month-old infant has progressive weakness, hypotonia, and an increased startle response. The presence of a mutation that causes decreased hexosaminidase A activity confirms the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for genetic counseling prior to conception. Her younger brother has mild developmental delay, pale complexion, and has to limit his dietary intake of phenylalanine. She has no similar symptoms and is in good health. Her parents are healthy. Which of the following is the most appropriate assessment of her carrier status for the disease affecting her brother?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This woman's parents had a 25% chance of having a child who is unaffected and not a carrier (AA), a 50% chance of having a child who is a heterozygous (Aa) carrier, and a 25% chance of having a child who is affected (aa). Since this woman is phenotypically unaffected, she has a 0% chance of being homozygous (aa). Therefore, she has a 33.3% chance of not being a carrier (AA) and a 66.7% chance of being a carrier (Aa).
Image Description:

In an autosomal recessive inheritance, two copies of a disease allele (a) located on autosomes are needed to be passed from the parents to the offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype. In this inheritance pattern, affected individuals are present not in every generation. Males and females are equally affected. The parents of an affected individual are usually not affected but carry the causative allele. Autosomal recessive inheritance is common in consanguineous families because of the increased risk of carriage of recessive alleles.

A: healthy allele

B) INCORRECT:

This represents the likelihood of the patient being genotypically and phenotypically healthy, without being a carrier (e.g., homozygous AA).

Recognize phenylketonuria, and calculate the carrier status probability in the first-degree sibling of a patient with an autosomal recessive disease.

Identify phenylketonuria and calculate carrier probability in first-degree sibling of autosomal recessive disease patient.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient would have a 100% chance of being a heterozygous carrier (Aa) if one parent were phenotypically and genotypically healthy (e.g., AA) and the other parent were phenotypically affected (aa), or if her parents were a heterozygous carrier (Aa) and phenotypically affected (aa).

D) INCORRECT:

This woman's parents had a 75% overall chance that their child would be asymptomatic (i.e., phenotypically healthy); 25% (AA) plus 50% (Aa). Considering that this woman cannot be homozygous for the phenylketonuria allele (aa), her individual chance of being a heterozygous carrier (Aa) is not 75%.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient would have a 50% chance of being a heterozygous carrier (Aa) if her health status was unknown. However, we know that this woman is phenotypically unaffected. Therefore, she cannot be homozygous for the phenylketonuria allele (aa) and her individual chance of being a heterozygous carrier (Aa) is not 50%.
questions.hint: Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disease, which means both of the patient's parents must be heterozygous carriers (Aa) as they are both phenotypically unaffected and have a phenotypically affected child (aa).

questions.text: A previously healthy 42-year-old man comes to the emergency room with constipation and diffuse, worsening abdominal pain for 2 days. He has no history of major medical illness. His father died in a car accident at the age of 32 years, and his mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus but is otherwise healthy. A diagnosis of bowel obstruction is suspected and he is taken to the operating room for exploratory laparotomy. A partial resection of the colon is performed. The gross appearance of the patient's colonic tissue is shown. Microscopic examination shows tubular, tubulovillous, and villous adenomas. Assuming the patient's partner is not a carrier of the condition, which of the following is the likelihood that this patient’s children will develop this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the patient is a homozygous dominant (i.e. two dominant/diseased alleles), there is a 100% probability of passing down a dominant allele to his offspring. Almost all individuals with an autosomal dominant disease have only one affected parent and are thus genetically heterozygous. Even if this man developed a de novo mutation, the probability is exceptionally rare that he developed two de novo mutations in the same gene locus on both alleles, so he would be assumed to be heterozygous as well.

B) INCORRECT:

When both parents are heterozygous for an autosomal recessive disease, the chance of disease inheritance is 25%. FAP is autosomal dominant, not autosomal recessive. Furthermore, there is one affected parent and no carriers in this scenario.

C) INCORRECT:

When both parents are heterozygous for an autosomal dominant disease, the chance of disease inheritance is 75% (50% heterozygous and 25% homozygous dominant). FAP is an autosomal dominant disease, but only one parent is affected in this scenario.

D) CORRECT:

FAP is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the APC tumor suppressor gene. It can be determined that this patient is heterozygous (i.e., one dominant/disease allele) because his mother is otherwise healthy. In addition, his partner has no FAP (i.e., two recessive/healthy alleles). Therefore, the patient's child has a 50% chance of inheriting one dominant allele and developing FAP.
Image Description:

In autosomal dominant inheritance, only one copy of a disease allele located on autosomes is needed to be passed to cause the expression of the phenotype in an offspring. In this inheritance pattern, there are affected individuals in each generation. Males and females are equally affected. At least one parent of the affected individual carries the disease allele and is affected. Affected males can inherit the phenotype from the affected mother, and affected females can inherit the phenotype from the affected father.

E) INCORRECT:

Some patients have no family history of FAP because they developed a de novo mutation. Regardless of past family history, once the mutation is established in an individual, FAP will be passed down to offspring in an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

In an exceedingly rare case of mosaicism, certain somatic cells will carry the de novo mutation for FAP while other cells, such as germ cells, will not. This scenario can lead to a 0% probability of disease in the offspring, but mosaicism should not be assumed unless otherwise stated.
questions.hint: This patient has hundreds of colonic polyps with varying histology, consistent with a diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because he and his wife have been unable to conceive a child despite having regular unprotected sexual intercourse. He is 187 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb). Examination shows long extremities, bilateral gynecomastia, and small, firm testes. A peripheral blood smear shows a dense, dark-staining spot at the periphery of the nucleus of a cell. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the finding on this patient's peripheral blood smear?

choices.text: Impaired removal of RBC nuclei remnants

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Histone acetylation relaxes DNA coiling and allows RNA polymerase and transcription factors to access DNA, which enhances gene transcription. This process is not responsible for the creation of the Barr bodies seen on this patient's peripheral blood smear.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired removal of RBC nuclei remnants results in Howell-Jolly bodies, which can be seen as dark spots in erythrocytes on peripheral blood smear in patients with asplenia. This process is not responsible for the creation of the Barr bodies seen on this patient's peripheral blood smear.
Image Description:

Peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain)

Numerous erythrocytes (light pink disc-like structures with central pallor) can be seen throughout the image. Howell-Jolly bodies are visible as small circular basophilic inclusions in the cytoplasm of the three erythrocytes (red overlay). A neutrophil with a polysegmented basophilic nucleus (in the center) and a lymphocyte with a large central round nucleus and a rim of basophilic cytoplasm (on the right side) are also visible.

Howell-Jolly bodies are usually removed by the spleen. They are typically seen in asplenic patients but can also appear in individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes or megaloblastic anemia.

C) CORRECT:

Methylation of cytosine nucleotides is the most common epigenetic modification of human DNA. DNA methylation, which is performed by DNA methyltransferases, typically occurs within a gene promoter (CpG islands) and results in inhibition of gene transcription. This mechanism is involved in the X chromosome inactivation and leads to the formation of Barr bodies, as seen on this patient's peripheral blood smear. On electron microscopy, methylated DNA is seen as heterochromatin.

DNA methylation is also involved in genomic imprinting, repression of transposable elements, aging, and cancer development.
Image Description:

Peripheral blood smear (Wright-Giemsa stain; 100x magnification)

Two neutrophils can be seen among numerous RBCs. Within one of the neutrophils (dashed outline), a Barr body (yellow overlay) and an aberrant barbed-wire nuclear projection (red overlay) are visible.

Barr bodies and aberrant nuclear projections are seen in chromosomal trisomy (e.g., in Klinefelter syndrome).

D) INCORRECT:

Aggregation of ribosomes results in basophilic stippling, which occurs in immature erythrocytes (e.g., due to lead poisoning, thalassemias, and myelodysplastic syndromes). Basophilic stippling is seen as small blue dots in erythrocytes on a peripheral blood smear. This process is not responsible for the creation of the Barr bodies seen on this patient's peripheral blood smear.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (Pappenheim stain)

The erythrocytes contain purple spots (green overlay), which are consistent with cytoplasmic granules. The large, heavily spotted cell in the center of the right image appears to be a neutrophil. In the center of the left image, there is a normoblast with a prominent nucleus, which is not usually present in peripheral blood and suggests impaired erythropoiesis.

Basophilic stippling describes the appearance of red blood granules, which are mainly composed of aggregating ribosomes. It is characteristic of impaired red blood cell maturation.

E) INCORRECT:

Aggregation of oxidized hemoglobin results in Heinz bodies, which can be seen as dark spots in erythrocytes on peripheral blood smear in patients with G6PD deficiency. This process is not responsible for the creation of the Barr bodies seen on this patient's peripheral blood smear.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear (new methylene blue stain; high magnification)

Multiple erythrocytes are visible, some of which contain small, round inclusions (examples indicated by arrowheads) called Heinz bodies. Heinz bodies are composed of denatured hemoglobin and are typically associated with G6PD deficiency but are also seen in other conditions.
questions.hint: This man has Klinefelter syndrome, a condition that causes testicular hypoplasia, impaired fertility, gynecomastia, and tall, slender stature. Affected patients most commonly have a 47, XXY karyotype; the additional X chromosome may be visible as a Barr body on peripheral blood smear.

questions.text: A healthy 29-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for genetic counseling prior to conception. Her brother has a disease that has resulted in infertility, a right-sided heart, and frequent sinus and ear infections. No other family members are affected. The intended father's family history of this disease is unknown and he is asymptomatic. The population prevalence of this disease is 1 in 40,000. Which of the following best represents the chance that this patient’s offspring will develop her brother's disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

0.7% is an incorrect answer that might be selected because of a calculation error. The chance of having an affected offspring = (probability of each parent passing on the affected gene) * (probability that each patient is a carrier). For this case, if one does not take into account the 50% chance that each potential heterozygote parent has of passing on the affected gene, they would incorrectly arrive at the answer of 0.7%.

B) INCORRECT:

The probability of the patient's partner being a heterozygous carrier for Kartagener syndrome is 1%. This is not, however, the chance that the patient's offspring will develop the disease. Using the Hardy-Weinberg principle, if the population prevalence (q2) is 1/40,000, then the diseased allele frequency (q) is √(1/40,000) = 1/200. The normal allele frequency (p) = 1-(diseased allele frequency) = 1-q = 1-(1/200) = 199/200. The chance of the patient's partner being a heterozygous carrier is 2pq = 2*(199/200)*(1/200) = 199/20,000 = .00995*100 = 0.995% ≈ 1%.

C) INCORRECT:

If there was 100% certainty that the patient and the father were both heterozygote carriers for Kartagener syndrome, then the chance that this patient’s offspring would develop the disease would be 25%, because both parents would have a 50% chance of passing on the affected gene. The chance of having an affected offspring = (probability of each parent passing on the affected gene) * (probability that each patient is a carrier): (1/2)(1) * (1/2)(1) = 25%. Note that 25% is actually the probability of this patient's parents having an offspring with the disease; this is not the chance that the patient's offspring will develop the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient's chance that she is a healthy heterozygous carrier of Kartagener syndrome is 66%, but this is not the chance that the patient's offspring will develop the disease. Since this patient does not have the disease, she cannot carry two recessive traits. Therefore, she has a ⅔ chance (66%) of being a carrier and a ⅓ chance (33%) of not inheriting the mutation.

E) INCORRECT:

Using the Hardy-Weinberg principle, if the population prevalence (q2) is 1/40,000, then the diseased allele frequency (q) is √(1/40,000) = 1/200 = 0.005*100 = 0.5%. The diseased allele frequency is the probability of someone carrying the allele, which is not equivalent to the probability of the patient's offspring developing Kartagener syndrome (i.e., being homozygous).

F) CORRECT:

In an autosomal recessive disease, an offspring of two heterozygote parents has a ½ chance of being a carrier of the mutation (heterozygote), a ¼ chance of having the disease, and a ¼ chance of not inheriting the mutation at all. Since this patient does not have the disease, she cannot carry two recessive traits. Therefore, she has a ⅔ chance of being a carrier (½ / ¾), and a ⅓ chance of not having inherited the mutation.

For the patient's partner, the genotype of the parents is unknown, and the heterozygote frequency is calculated by using the Hardy-Weinberg law: (p+q)2 = p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1, where 2pq is the chance of being a heterozygous carrier, p2 is the homozygote frequency of the normal allele, and q2 is the homozygote frequency of the diseased allele (i.e., the population prevalence). If the population prevalence (q2) is 1/40,000, then the diseased allele frequency (q) = √(1/40,000) = 1/200. The normal allele frequency (p) = 1-(diseased allele frequency) = 1-q = 1-(1/200) = 199/200. Therefore, the partner's chance of being a heterozygous carrier is 2pq = 2*(199/200)*(1/200) = 2*199/40,000 = 199/20,000 = .00995.

To determine the probability of the child inheriting the affected allele from the mother AND from the father (i.e., having the disease in an autosomal recessive disease), the probabilities of each parent being a heterozygous carrier AND passing on that allele have to be multiplied by each other according to the multiplication rule (conditional probability). The probability of a heterozygote carrier passing on an affected allele is 50%. Therefore, the calculation would be (1/2)(2/3) * (1/2)(199/20,000) = 0.0017 = ∼ 0.2% in this case.

To simplify the calculation, consider rounding (p) up from 199/200 to 1. The partner's chance of being a heterozygous carrier can be solved with the following equation: 2pq = 2*(1)*(1/200) = 2/200 = 1/100. Thereafter, the final calculation is (1/2)(2/3) * (1/2)(1/100) = ∼ 0.2%
questions.hint: The combination of infertility, a right-sided heart, and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections is consistent with Kartagener syndrome, which is an autosomal recessive condition. The probability of the offspring developing the condition (i.e., being homozygous) depends on the probability of the parents being heterozygous AND passing on the affected allele. Since the patient's brother has the condition but both her parents are asymptomatic, the parents must be carriers for this trait (heterozygous). Mendelian principles are used to calculate the patient's probability of being a heterozygous carrier. The Hardy-Weinberg principle is used to calculate the husband's probability of being a heterozygous carrier. Finally, the probability of the offspring having the condition (i.e., being homozygous) can be calculated with conditional probability rules.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia comes to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period for 12 months. Menarche occurred at the age of 11 years, and menses occurred at regular 28-day intervals until they became irregular 1 year ago. Physical examination shows normal female genitalia and bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated FSH levels consistent with premature ovarian failure. Fluorescence in situ hybridization studies show a 46,XY karyotype in the peripheral blood cells. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the male karyotype found on chromosomal analysis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Allogeneic stem cell transplantation is used in post-remission therapy of patients with ALL who have a high risk of relapse. In contrast to autologous stem cell transplantation, which involves the removal, storage, and retransfusion of a patient's own cells, allogenous stem cell transplantation refers to the administration of hematopoietic stem cells from a sibling or unrelated donor. Chromosomal analysis in this female patient shows a male genotype (46,XY karyotype) because she received stem cells from a male donor (e.g., sex-mismatched transplantation). This patient's premature ovarian failure is most likely related to cytotoxic effects of chemotherapy and radiation administered prior to the allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

Other types of grafts include isografts (e.g., from an identical twin) and xenografts (e.g., from a pig).

B) INCORRECT:

Müllerian duct agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) is a rare, congenital defect that manifests with normally functioning gonads, female phenotype, and primary amenorrhea due to a missing or abnormal uterus. In contrast to this patient, premature ovarian failure and male genotype on FISH analysis would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

21-hydroxylase deficiency is seen in patients with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), a group of autosomal recessive defects in the enzymes responsible for cortisol, aldosterone, and androgen synthesis. In contrast to this patient, 21-hydroxylase deficiency in women most commonly manifests with hypotension, virilization, and precocious puberty. Although menstrual irregularities can occur in CAH, the mechanism differs from premature ovarian failure. It would not explain the male genotype seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiation is used as CNS preventive therapy in patients with ALL, and it has been associated with amenorrhea and premature ovarian failure due to cytotoxic effects on oocytes. However, radiotherapy of the CNS would not cause a male genotype on FISH, which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Defective androgen receptor function is the underlying cause of androgen insensitivity syndrome, an X-linked recessive mutation of the gene locus encoding the androgen receptor. Patients present with amenorrhea, variable degrees of feminization, and a 46,XY karyotype. However, a blind vaginal pouch, uterine agenesis, and primary amenorrhea (rather than secondary amenorrhea) would also be expected.
questions.hint: This woman with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) has secondary amenorrhea due to premature ovarian failure, most likely related to chemotherapy she received in the past. Physical examination shows a female phenotype, whereas chromosomal analysis shows a male genotype.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of blurry vision. He is at the 97th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. He has long, slender fingers and toes that are hyperflexible. Examination of the oropharynx shows a high-arched palate. Slit lamp examination shows bilateral lens subluxation in the superotemporal direction. The patient's older sister is also tall, has hyperflexible joints, and has hyperelastic skin. However, she does not have lens subluxation or an arched palate. Which of the following genetic principles accounts for the phenotypical differences seen in this pair of siblings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Penetrance refers to the ratio of patients with a disease-causing allele to the patients expressing the disease phenotype. Incomplete penetrance refers to the phenomenon in which not all patients who possess the mutated allele are affected by the disease. For example, patients with Lynch syndrome have an autosomal dominant mutation in DNA mismatch repair enzymes that predisposes them to numerous cancers (especially colorectal cancer), but ∼ 20–30% of patients who carry the Lynch syndrome mutation do not develop colorectal cancer. This patient and his sister are both phenotypically affected by Marfan syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Marfan syndrome is a condition caused by a mutation of fibrillin-1 gene (FBN1) on chromosome 15. Although this mutation has resulted in defective fibrillin in both the patient and his sister, the condition manifests differently between the two. Different phenotypic expression in patients with the same genotype is a phenomenon known as variable expressivity. Individuals with the same mutation may display different symptoms, age of onset, and disease severity.

C) INCORRECT:

Compound heterozygosity is the phenomenon in which an autosomal recessive disease can be caused by possession of two differently mutated alleles at a particular gene locus, resulting in a loss-of-function mutation of the affected gene. Many autosomal recessive diseases can be caused by compound heterozygosity, including Wilson disease, phenylketonuria, and cystic fibrosis. Compound heterozygosity is not associated with autosomal dominant diseases, such as Marfan syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Frameshift mutation refers to the insertion or deletion of nucleotides that are not divisible by 3 in a sequence of DNA. This shifts the reading frame and causes a different set of codons, resulting in a different amino acid chain after translation that can alter protein structure and function. Frameshift mutation is associated with the pathogenesis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy and Tay-Sachs disease but it does not explain the different manifestations of Marfan syndrome in this patient and his sister.

E) INCORRECT:

Chromosomal instability refers to a mutation in genes involved in DNA repair. Under normal conditions, the process of cell replication is followed by mismatch repair to preserve the integrity of the genome. When the genes that encode for these repair proteins are mutated, errors in cell division are not repaired and are passed down through the cell lineage, accounting for an increased number of mutated cells. Chromosomal instability is associated with the pathogenesis of Fanconi anemia, ataxia telangiectasia, and certain tumors (especially colorectal cancer), but it does not explain the different manifestations of Marfan syndrome in this patient and his sister.
questions.hint: This patient presents with tall stature, a high-arched palate, arachnodactyly (long, thin fingers), hypermobile joints, and superotemporal lens subluxation, which are highly characteristic of Marfan syndrome. His sister also has features consistent with this disease. This should be expected, considering the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance that Marfan syndrome follows.

questions.text: A 3500-g (7 lb 11 oz) healthy female newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) in the first trimester showed a trisomy of chromosome 21 but the pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated. Physical examination of the newborn is normal. Chromosomal analysis at birth shows a 46, XX karyotype. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the prenatal chromosomal abnormality?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Locus heterogeneity occurs when mutations in genes at different chromosomal loci cause the same phenotype. This means that two individuals with the same disease might have a different genotype; however, this would not cause a genetic discrepancy within an individual's tissue and does not explain the normal phenotype of the newborn.

B) INCORRECT:

Maternal uniparental disomy is a genetic anomaly in which the individual inherits two of the same chromosomes from one parent and none from the other. Uniparental disomy does not lead to polysomy and therefore would not explain the presence of trisomy 21 in the placental tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 21 is an example of phenotypic pleiotropy, in which one gene contributes to different phenotypic effects. Affected patients may display several developmental deformities, such as a palmar crease, upward slanting palpebral fissure, and cardiac defects. However, pleiotropy would not explain this patient's normal phenotype or the discrepancy between her placental and actual genotype.

D) INCORRECT:

Incomplete penetrance is the phenomenon by which not all individuals with a mutant genotype express the corresponding phenotype. However, trisomy 21 is typically not associated with incomplete penetrance. Furthermore, it would not explain the chromosomal discordance between the chorionic villus sample and the newborn tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Maternal heteroplasmy refers to the presence of heterogeneous mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in an individual. Because all mitochondria are inherited from the mother, mitochondrial diseases that develop in utero are a result of unequal distribution of normal and mutated mtDNA molecules during mitosis. Thus, genetic discrepancies in a patient can be observed depending on which cells are sampled. However, trisomy 21 is a polysomy that affects the nuclear genome, not the mitochondrial genome.
Image Description:

Following de novo mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), cells have both mutated and normal mitochondria, which is known as heteroplasmy. When there is heteroplasmy in the parental cell (P), levels of heteroplasmy can increase, decrease, or stay the same in subsequent filial generations (F1, F2), resulting in variable disease expression. Severity often correlates with the proportion of mutated mtDNA. In some conditions, the disease phenotype is only expressed once the proportion of mutated mtDNA is above a certain threshold.

F) INCORRECT:

Variable expressivity is the mechanism by which mutations result in varying degrees of phenotypic severity. Patients with trisomy 21 often have varying degrees of clinical severity despite having the same genetic anomaly. However, variable expressivity does not explain the genetic discordance between the newborn and placental tissue.

G) CORRECT:

In CVS, a sample from the placenta is taken to test for chromosomal abnormalities, rather than direct fetal tissue. In rare cases, there is a discrepancy between the sampled placental genotype and that of the fetus (mosaicism of the placenta). In confined placental mosaicism, the CVS may show an abnormal genotype but the fetus has a normal genotype, as seen here.
questions.hint: This genetic phenomenon occurs in about 1–2% of all pregnancies in which chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is performed.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man and his wife come to the physician for preconception genetic counseling. The patient and his wife are asymptomatic and have no history of serious illness. His older brother died at age 13 from heart failure and his 6-year-old nephew currently has severe muscle weakness. Genetic testing shows that the patient's mother is not a somatic carrier of the mutation that is responsible for the disease in his relatives. A pedigree chart of his family is shown; the patient is marked with an asterisk. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient not being affected?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Variable expressivity describes a phenomenon in which phenotypic expression varies among individuals with the same genotype. Conditions that manifest with variable expressivity include neurofibromatosis type 1 and Marfan syndrome. Patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy will express the same phenotype, characterized by the onset of proximal muscle weakness and a waddling gait before the age of 5 years, calf pseudohypertrophy, inability to ambulate without support by adolescence, and early death from heart failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Maternal uniparental disomy is an anomaly in which an individual receives 2 copies of a chromosome from the mother and no copy from the father; it can occur due to errors in meiosis I or meiosis II and should be considered when an afflicted child has a recessive disease and only the mother is a carrier. However, the patient's mother is not a carrier for the condition. Moreover, Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease, and so a euploid individual with X-chromosomal maternal uniparental disomy would be female, unlike this male patient. Maternal uniparental disomy is responsible for approx. 25% of cases of Prader-Willi syndrome, which presents with obesity, hyperphagia, intellectual disability, hypogonadism, and hypotonia.

C) CORRECT:

Since the X chromosome cannot be inherited paternally in men, there are only 3 possibilities with respect to this patient: the patient's mother was a somatic carrier of DMD, the DMD mutation was acquired by the patient's brother after fertilization (somatic mutation), or the mutation was generated de-novo in at least some of the X chromosome-containing haploid germ cells of the patient's mother (gonadal mosaicism). It is known that the patient's mother is not a somatic carrier of DMD. A post-fertilization mutation affecting the patient's brother is also unlikely because the patient's sister is a carrier; it would be extremely rare for a post-fertilization mutation to affect the same locus of the same gene in 2 members of the same family. Therefore, it must be implied that at least some of the X chromosome-containing haploid germ cells of the patient's mother would have had the DMD mutation. Gonadal mosaicism occurs when some or all of the germline cells (eggs or sperm) are genetically distinct from the rest of the body as a result of de-novo mutations in primordial germ cells during mitosis. The patient has most likely been spared from DMD because his genotype was formed by a maternal ovum containing an unaffected X chromosome.

D) INCORRECT:

A dominant negative mutation involves the production of proteins that inhibit the function of the normal gene product in heterozygotes. This results in disease penetrance in every individual that carries the mutation. However, Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. Individuals heterozygous for the DMD mutation are carriers and not phenotypically afflicted with the disease. Marfan syndrome, which can cause heart failure due to chronic aortic regurgitation or mitral valve prolapse, is associated with a dominant negative mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene. However, Marfan syndrome does not cause severe muscle weakness or early death; instead, patients develop features such as long extremities, chest wall deformities, hypermobile joints, and visual disturbance due to lens subluxation.

E) INCORRECT:

Penetrance describes the probability that individuals with a disease-specific genotype will manifest with the disease's corresponding phenotype. Some mutations have incomplete penetrance (e.g., only 80% of individuals with mutations in the BRCA1 gene develop breast cancer), which could explain why a healthy mother has an affected son. Duchenne muscular dystrophy, however, has complete (100%) penetrance.
questions.hint: The symptom of early-onset severe muscle weakness leading to heart failure is suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene. A male adult who does not have muscle weakness would be negative for the DMD mutation. The patient's father would, therefore, have been negative for DMD, and the patient's sister was most likely a carrier because the patient's nephew has DMD.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a rapidly growing lump in her right breast. Eight months ago, she underwent excision of a liposarcoma from the dorsum of her right forearm. Her brother was diagnosed with osteosarcoma of the maxilla at the age of 22 years. Her mother died at the age of 43 years from complications of acute myeloid leukemia. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years. Examination shows a fixed, firm mass in the right breast with axillary lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma. Which of the following genetic principles is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Loss of heterozygosity in tumor suppressor gene
Methylation of a previously normal gene copy
Oncogenic transformation of a previously normal gene
Exposure to an oncogenic microbial infection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The development of malignancies in Li-Fraumeni syndrome occurs due to loss of heterozygosity in the p53 tumor suppressor gene. Affected individuals inherit one abnormal copy of the TP53 gene but only develop cancer once the second allele is somatically mutated or deleted, due to unregulated cell proliferation.

B) INCORRECT:

Methylation results in silencing of a gene copy and is the mechanism behind the genomic imprinting seen in Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome. However, this patient's diagnosis and family history suggest a hereditary syndrome in which a different genetic mechanism occurs.

C) INCORRECT:

Examples of oncogenic transformation of a previously normal gene (e.g., oncogene) include JAK-2 gene mutations (associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms), BRAF gene mutations (associated with melanoma, papillary thyroid cancer), and KRAS gene mutations (associated with colon cancer, lung cancer). Oncogenic transformation only requires a mutation in one allele of the respective proto-oncogene. This patient's diagnosis and family history suggest a hereditary syndrome in which a different genetic mechanism occurs.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic exposure to carcinogenic material can play a role in the development of individual cancer types (e.g., tobacco smoke and lung cancer, asbestos fibers and mesothelioma). However, it is unlikely to cause the constellation of malignancies seen in this patient and would not explain her family history. This patient's diagnosis and family history suggest a hereditary syndrome in which a different genetic mechanism occurs.

E) INCORRECT:

Examples of oncogenic microbial infections include HPV infection (associated with cervical cancer) and H. pylori infection (associated with gastric cancer). In this case, however, it is unlikely that this patient and her entire family was exposed to a pathogen that could cause such a variety of cancer types. This patient's diagnosis and family history suggest a hereditary syndrome due to a different genetic mechanism.
questions.hint: This patient has had multiple malignancies at an unusually early age. The history of multiple cancers in a first-degree relative suggests a hereditary component. Considering the type of cancers (sarcomas, breast cancer, leukemia) and age of onset in this family (all < 45 years), a diagnosis of Li-Fraumeni syndrome is highly likely.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician for genetic counseling prior to conception. For the past year, she has had intermittent episodes of headache, nausea, abdominal pain, and tingling of her fingers. She also reports dark urine during the episodes. Her mother and maternal uncle have similar symptoms and her father is healthy. Her husband is healthy and there is no history of serious illness in his family. Serum studies show elevated concentrations of porphobilinogen and δ-aminolevulinic acid. Which of the following is the probability of this patient having a child with the same disease as her?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In autosomal recessive conditions, a phenotypically unaffected child of heterozygous parents (Aa) has an approx. 67% chance of also being an asymptomatic carrier of the affected allele (Aa). In autosomal dominant conditions, such as AIP, every offspring with at least one mutated allele will be affected.

B) CORRECT:

AIP is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in porphobilinogen deaminase. This patient must be heterozygous (Aa) for the disease because she is affected, but her father is healthy (aa). As her husband is phenotypically normal, he cannot be a carrier of a mutated copy of the gene. This woman has a 50% chance of passing on the affected allele, which would cause the disease. Therefore, the risk of having an affected child is ½ or 50%.

See "AD inheritance pattern in heterozygous and homozygous parent” table.
Image Description:

In autosomal dominant inheritance, only one copy of a disease allele located on autosomes is needed to be passed to cause the expression of the phenotype in an offspring. In this inheritance pattern, there are affected individuals in each generation. Males and females are equally affected. At least one parent of the affected individual carries the disease allele and is affected. Affected males can inherit the phenotype from the affected mother, and affected females can inherit the phenotype from the affected father.

C) INCORRECT:

In autosomal recessive conditions, the chance of having an affected child is 25% if both parents are heterozygous carriers of the affected allele (Aa). However, acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant condition. Therefore, inheritance of one affected allele would already cause the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

In autosomal dominant conditions, such as acute intermittent porphyria, the chance of having an affected child is 100% if at least one of the parents is homozygous for the affected allele (AA). This patient must be heterozygous (Aa) for the disease because she is affected, but her father is healthy (aa).

E) INCORRECT:

In autosomal recessive conditions, the chance of having a phenotypically affected child is 0% if one parent is homozygous for the normal allele. Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant condition. Therefore, inheritance of one affected allele would already cause the disease.
questions.hint: This patient has episodes of headaches, abdominal pain, nausea, paresthesias, and dark urine, in the setting of elevated porphobilinogen (PBG) and δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) concentrations. This indicates acute intermittent porphyria (AIP).

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because his vision has worsened rapidly over the last 2 months. His maternal uncle lost his vision suddenly over a period of 3 months at 26 years of age. The patient's wife and 1-year-old son have normal vision. Funduscopic examination of the patient shows bilateral circumpapillary telangiectasia. Genetic testing shows a missense mutation in one of the genes of the electron transport chain complexes. The probability that this patient's son will be affected by the same disease is closest to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Leber hereditary optic neuropathy typically presents with acute monocular vision loss in a young adult followed by contralateral vision loss in the following weeks or months. A family history of similar ocular disease is common. The condition is passed exclusively from mother to child (as are all diseases inherited via mitochondrial DNA) since mitochondria from sperm cells are not transmitted during fertilization. Offspring of affected males, therefore, are at the same risk as the general population (about 1 in 50,000). Other conditions that demonstrate mitochondrial inheritance include mitochondrial myopathies (e.g., MERRF or MELAS syndrome).
Image Description:

Mitochondrial inheritance implies transmission of the disease only through the mother. All the offsprings of affected females may express the phenotype. Variable expression is observed due to heteroplasmy.

B) INCORRECT:

This is the probability that would be observed in autosomal recessive disorders, with both parents being heterozygous (silent carriers) for the recessive allele. This patient's vision loss is due to an inherited mitochondrial disorder, which follows a different inheritance pattern than autosomal recessive diseases.
Image Description:

In an autosomal recessive inheritance, two copies of a disease allele (a) located on autosomes are needed to be passed from the parents to the offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype. In this inheritance pattern, affected individuals are present not in every generation. Males and females are equally affected. The parents of an affected individual are usually not affected but carry the causative allele. Autosomal recessive inheritance is common in consanguineous families because of the increased risk of carriage of recessive alleles.

A: healthy allele

C) INCORRECT:

The simplest scenario in which multiples of ⅓ factor into genetics calculations are those involving carriers. For example, given two parents who are heterozygous for an autosomal recessive allele and their unaffected offspring with unknown genotype, the odds of their offspring not being a carrier are 33% (the homozygous recessive phenotype is eliminated in an unaffected individual, leaving a 33% chance of homozygous dominant and a 66% chance of heterozygous). This patient's condition is governed by the rules of mitochondrial inheritance and does not follow such a pattern.

D) INCORRECT:

This is the probability that would be observed if the patient's vision loss was attributable to an autosomal dominant disorder. In such a scenario, the affected parent has one copy of the mutated allele and the unaffected parent has two normal alleles. In contrast, this patient's vision loss is due to an inherited mitochondrial disorder, so a different inheritance pattern is expected.
Image Description:

In autosomal dominant inheritance, only one copy of a disease allele located on autosomes is needed to be passed to cause the expression of the phenotype in an offspring. In this inheritance pattern, there are affected individuals in each generation. Males and females are equally affected. At least one parent of the affected individual carries the disease allele and is affected. Affected males can inherit the phenotype from the affected mother, and affected females can inherit the phenotype from the affected father.

E) INCORRECT:

This would be the probability of passing a disease to an offspring where both parents each had the same autosomal dominant mutated allele (e.g. both parents have autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease) or both parents had two autosomal recessive alleles (e.g. both parents have the same mutation causing cystic fibrosis). Such scenarios are exceptionally uncommon. Moreover, this patient's vision loss is due to an inherited mitochondrial disorder, which follows a different inheritance pattern.
questions.hint: Rapidly worsening vision, circumpapillary telangiectasia on fundoscopy, and a mutation affecting the mitochondrial electron transport chain are diagnostic of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive difficulty climbing stairs for the last 2 years. During this period, he has also had problems running and standing up from a seated position. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows enlarged calf muscles bilaterally and a waddling gait. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonsense mutations are point mutations that cause insertion of a premature stop codon, which results in a nonfunctional protein or gene product. About 10%–15% of cases of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) are due to a nonsense mutation in the dystrophin gene. The disease typically manifests in boys with symptoms identical to BMD such as progressive muscle weakness and calf pseudohypertrophy, which are seen in this patient. However, symptoms manifest during infancy or early childhood and are more severe than in BMD.

As certain nonsense mutations can induce exon skipping and thereby produce various phenotypes, nonsense mutations within exon 1 or 27 have indeed been associated with a BMD phenotype. However, these mutations are exceptions, and another mechanism is much more likely in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder that is most commonly caused by an in-frame deletion in the dystrophin gene, which leads to a partially functional protein. In in-frame mutations, multiples of three nucleotides (i.e., complete codons) are added or deleted, leaving the reading frame intact. The second most common cause of BMD is a missense mutation, where a single nucleotide is substituted. BMD usually manifests in boys during adolescence or early adulthood with slow, progressive muscle weakness and calf pseudohypertrophy, as seen in this patient. Symptoms are typically less severe and appear later than in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

Genetic analysis for mutations in the dystrophin gene is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis of dystrophinopathies.

C) INCORRECT:

Trinucleotide repeat expansions cause a variety of diseases including myotonic dystrophy (MD, CTG repeats) and Friedreich ataxia (FA, GAA repeats). MD and FA both manifest with progressive weakness. However, MD is associated with muscle pain and atrophy (not pseudohypertrophy), and patients often develop cardiac arrhythmias, testicular atrophy, frontal baldness, and/or cataracts, which are not seen this patient. While FA also manifests with gait difficulties, this is due to a spastic paresis that affects the entire lower leg, leading to a wide-based, staggering gait, which is not present in this patient. Moreover, one would expect an onset of symptoms during childhood and different findings, including nystagmus, diabetes mellitus, and skeletal deformities. FA does not cause calf pseudohypertrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Splice site mutations are associated with a variety of diseases including cancers, dementia, epilepsy, and some types of β-thalassemia. However, they are not an underlying cause of muscular dystrophy.

E) INCORRECT:

Frameshift mutations cause insertion or deletion of nucleotides, which changes the originally-encoded sequence of triplets and thus shifts the way it is read during translation. X-linked recessive frameshift mutations of the dystrophin gene are a common cause of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). The disease typically manifests in boys with symptoms identical to BMD such as progressive muscle weakness and calf pseudohypertrophy, which are seen in this patient. However, symptoms in DMD manifest during infancy or early childhood and are more severe than symptoms in BMD.
questions.hint: Proximal muscle weakness in the lower extremities (difficulty climbing stairs, standing from a seated position, waddling gait), bilateral calf pseudohypertrophy, and onset of symptoms during adolescence is highly suggestive of Becker muscular dystrophy.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, vomiting, and fatigue for the past 4 hours. Over the past month, she has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss, increased thirst, and increased urinary frequency. Examination shows dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, and hyperventilation with a fruity odor. Laboratory studies show a blood glucose level of 420 mg/dL and acetoacetate in the urine. Which of the following is the most likely inheritance pattern of this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autosomal recessive inheritance is seen in a small minority of patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus. Rare diabetic syndromes, such as mutations in the insulin receptor genes, are characterized by this inheritance pattern, but the vast majority of type 1 diabetics inherit the disease via a different pattern. Important autosomal recessive conditions include cystic fibrosis, sickle cell anemia, and ARPKD.

B) INCORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is not a condition with mitochondrial inheritance. Important examples of mitochondrially inherited conditions include mitochondrial myopathies (e.g., MELAS syndrome) and Leber hereditary optic neuropathy.

Family history is very important in mitochondrially-inherited diseases because the genes involved come exclusively from the mother. The clinical condition is, therefore, virtually never present in the paternal branch of the pedigree.

C) INCORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is not an X-linked recessive condition, which it would be unlikely for a female to be afflicted with in the first place. Important examples of X-linked recessive conditions include glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, hemophilia A and hemophilia B, and Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is not typically inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. Maturity-onset diabetes of the young is an autosomal dominant condition, but it is relatively rare. Important examples of autosomal dominant conditions include osteogenesis imperfecta, Marfan syndrome, ADPKD, hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, and Lynch syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

An imprinted gene is one in which one allele is silenced by methylation while the other allele is expressed. Important examples of conditions associated with the inheritance of imprinted genes include Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. Type 1 diabetes mellitus is not a condition associated with the inheritance of an imprinted gene.

F) CORRECT:

A polygenic trait is one that is controlled by the interaction of two or more genes at different loci. Skin color, eye color, and most anthropometric traits (e.g., height, weight) are the result of polygenic inheritance. Polygenic inheritance is also implicated in the pathogenesis of many common diseases such as type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, androgenic alopecia, atopy, schizophrenia, and Alzheimer disease. Polygenic traits do not follow Mendelian laws of inheritance.

A polygenic phenotype should not be confused with a codominant phenotype, in which both the alleles of a single gene are responsible for a particular phenotype.
questions.hint: This pediatric patient with severely elevated blood glucose has type 1 diabetes mellitus. The fruity breath odor and acetoacetate in the urine indicate that the patient is in diabetic ketoacidosis, a serious complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 18 weeks' gestation, comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She recently read about a genetic disorder that manifests with gait ataxia, kyphoscoliosis, and arrhythmia and is concerned about the possibility of her child inheriting the disease. There is no personal or family history of this disorder. The frequency of unaffected carriers in the general population is 1/100. Assuming the population is in a steady state without selection, what is the probability that her child will develop this disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

2pq represents the percentage of heterozygous (unaffected) carriers, which is 1/100 in this question. If q2 (i.e., the frequency of homozygosity for the mutated allele) is 1/10,000, then the frequency of the q allele is 1/100, which suggests that the frequency of the p allele is 99/100. However, this would require the frequency of heterozygous carriers (2pq) to be about 2/100 (i.e., 2 x 1/100 x 99/100), instead of 1/100.

B) INCORRECT:

2pq represents the percentage of heterozygous (unaffected) carriers, which is 1/100 in this question. If q2 (i.e., the frequency of homozygosity for the mutated allele) is 1/20,000, then the frequency of the q allele is about 1/141, which suggests that the frequency of the p allele is about 140/141. However, this would require the frequency of heterozygous carriers (2pq) to be about 1.4/100 (i.e., 2 x 1/141 x 140/141), instead of 1/100.

C) CORRECT:

In this case, q refers to the mutated FXN allele, and p refers to the wild-type allele. The probability that a child in the general population will develop Friedreich ataxia is equal to q2, as heterozygous carriers would not develop this autosomal recessive disease. 2pq represents the percentage of heterozygous (unaffected) carriers, which is 1/100 in this case. Because this disease is very rare, the frequency for the wild-type allele (p) is approximately 1 (i.e., nearly 100%). Therefore, 2pq = 1/100 → 2 x (1) x q = 1/100 → q = 1/200. The probability that this patient's child will develop Friedreich ataxia (i.e., q2) is about 1/40,000.

D) INCORRECT:

2pq represents the percentage of heterozygous (unaffected) carriers, which is 1/100 in this question. If q2 (i.e., the frequency of homozygosity for the mutated allele) is 1/200, then the frequency of the q allele is about 1/14, which suggests that the frequency of the p allele is 13/14. However, this would require the frequency of heterozygous carriers (2pq) to be about 13/100 (i.e., 2 x 1/14 x 13/14), instead of 1/100.

E) INCORRECT:

2pq represents the percentage of heterozygous (unaffected) carriers, which is 1/100 in this question. If q2 (i.e., the frequency of homozygosity for the mutated allele) is 1/400, then the frequency of the q allele is 1/20, which suggests that the frequency of the p allele is 19/20. However, this would require the frequency of heterozygous carriers (2pq) to be about 9.5/100 (i.e., 2 x 1/20 x 19/20), instead of 1/100. Additionally, 1/400 reflects the risk of a child having this disorder if one parent is a known heterozygous carrier. The heterozygote parent's risk of passing on the recessive allele is ½, while the risk of the parent with an unknown genotype is ½ of 1/100 (the probability of being a carrier). Thus, the probability of the child being affected is ½ x ½ x 1/100 = 1/400.
questions.hint: Gait ataxia, kyphoscoliosis, and arrhythmia are classic manifestations of Friedreich ataxia, an autosomal recessive disease caused by expansion of GAA trinucleotide repeats in the FXN gene (i.e., frataxin protein) on chromosome 9. The Hardy-Weinberg equation is used to estimate the frequency of two alleles in the general population. For any two alleles (i.e., p and q) where p + q = 1, then (p + q)2 = p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a 6-week history of fatigue, fever, and recurrent epistaxis. She has a history of duodenal atresia and an atrioventricular septal defect. She is at the 5th percentile for height and 30th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Her hands are short and broad and there is a space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. Bone marrow aspirate shows leukocytosis with 50% lymphoblasts. Which of the following best explains this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A frameshift mutation in the X-linked dystrophin gene causes Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), which causes muscle weakness and dilated cardiomyopathy. DMD is not associated with an increased risk of ASD, duodenal atresia, or leukemia. A frameshift mutation is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

B) CORRECT:

Meiotic nondisjunction is a pathologic genetic mechanism that can lead to chromosomal aberrations. 95% of cases of trisomy 21 are caused by the meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21. In the majority of these cases, this nondisjunction occurs in meiosis I (70%). In 20% of cases, the nondisjunction occurs in meiosis II. In 5% of cases, it is due to paternal non-disjunction during spermatogenesis.

C) INCORRECT:

Deletion of a segment on chromosome 5 can lead to cri-du-chat syndrome. This genetic disease manifests with congenital heart defects (most commonly ventricular septal defect), intellectual disability, facial and skeletal malformations, and, most characteristically, a high-pitched voice. This patient has a history of an ASD, duodenal stenosis, and ALL, which are not typically seen in patients with cri-du-chat syndrome. Deletion of a chromosome segment is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Uniparental disomy is responsible for 25% of cases of Prader-Willi syndrome and 5% of cases of Angelman syndrome. These syndromes may manifest with short stature, as seen in this patient. However, neither of these conditions is associated with duodenal atresia, ASD, or ALL, and other common manifestations of these syndromes such as obesity, muscular hypotonia, epileptic seizures, and/or behavioral problems are not described in this patient. Uniparental disomy is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Mosaicism is a genetic condition that can cause trisomy 21. However, it is a very rare cause, accounting for about 1% of cases. Additionally, ALL, duodenal stenosis, and atrioventricular septal defect are less common in mosaic trisomy 21 because not all cells have the characteristic chromosomal aberration, which usually results in less severe symptoms.

Mosaicism is more common (50%) in patients with Turner syndrome, which can cause short stature, specific cardiac defects (e.g., bicuspid aortic valve, aortic coarctation) as well as an increased risk of certain tumors (e.g., cystic hygroma, ovarian gonadoblastoma).

F) INCORRECT:

Trinucleotide repeat expansion is a pathologic mechanism of Friedreich ataxia, fragile X syndrome, and myotonic dystrophy, which are associated with specific cardiac abnormalities (e.g., mitral valve prolapse in Fragile X syndrome, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in Friedreich ataxia, arrhythmias in myotonic dystrophy). None of these conditions are, however, associated with an increased risk of ASD, duodenal atresia, or ALL. Trinucleotide repeat expansion is not a mechanism for trisomy 21, which is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

G) INCORRECT:

Unbalanced Robertsonian translocation is a genetic variation that involves a translocation (genetics) of the long arms of acrocentric chromosomes, which is one possible genetic change leading to trisomy 21. However, this variation is relatively uncommon and is only found in about 4% of individuals with trisomy 21.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical findings (fatigue, fever, recurrent epistaxis, painless cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly) and laboratory findings (leukocytosis with lymphoblasts) are consistent with acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). ALL, duodenal atresia, atrioventricular septal defect, short stature, broad hands, and sandal gap are common manifestations of trisomy 21.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of short stature. He is at the 5th percentile for height, 65th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. Examination shows midface retrusion, a bulging forehead, and flattening of the nose. The extremities are disproportionately short. He was adopted and does not know his biological parents. The patient’s condition is an example of which of the following genetic phenomena?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticipation describes a phenomenon in which a genetic disease increases in severity over several generations or manifests earlier with each generation. It is seen in conditions caused by trinucleotide repeat expansions (e.g., Huntington disease, myotonic dystrophy, fragile X syndrome), in which the number of repeats can increase with each generation, resulting in a more severe or earlier phenotypic expression. Anticipation, however, does not occur in achondroplasia.

B) INCORRECT:

Variable expressivity describes a phenomenon in which clinical or phenotypic features differ among individuals that carry the same altered genotype. Many genetic diseases show some variability in expressivity of a phenotype, with manifestations ranging from mild to life-threatening (e.g., Marfan syndrome). Factors influencing expressivity include other genetic phenomena and epigenetic or environmental factors. However, all patients with achondroplasia typically show the same degree of expressivity.

C) INCORRECT:

Imprinting describes an epigenetic mechanism of gene regulation in which either the paternal or maternal allele of a gene is inactivated (imprinted) via DNA methylation while the other allele is expressed. This mechanism plays a role in the genetics of Angelman syndrome, in which the paternally inherited UBE3A gene is imprinted (silenced) while the corresponding maternal allele is deleted or mutated. Imprinting also plays a role in Prader-Willi syndrome, in which genetic information on the maternal chromosome 15 is imprinted (silenced) while the corresponding allele on the paternal allele is deleted or mutated. However, achondroplasia is not caused by imprinting.

D) INCORRECT:

Allelic heterogeneity describes a phenomenon in which different mutations within a given gene can lead to the same disease. Depending on the type of mutation, the functional consequences can range from mild to significant, resulting in a large variety of phenotypic expressions. Examples include β-thalassemia and G6PD deficiency. Achondroplasia, however, is always caused by a gain-of-function mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 gene and is not associated with allelic heterogeneity.

E) CORRECT:

Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder with complete penetrance, meaning that all carriers of the altered genotype (i.e., a gain-of-function mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 gene) will be affected by the condition. Complete penetrance typically occurs when the phenotype is mostly determined by a single gene, such as in achondroplasia. Further examples of genetic conditions with full penetrance include Huntington disease and neurofibromatosis type I.
Image Description:

Short stature and prominent lumbar lordosis can be seen in this 11-year-old patient.

This is the characteristic appearance of achondroplasia.

F) INCORRECT:

Codominance describes a phenomenon in which both alleles of a gene contribute to phenotypic expression. For example, in the ABO blood group system, the blood groups A and B are codominant. However, achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disease in which only the mutant allele determines the phenotype.
questions.hint: This patient's short stature, distinctive craniofacial features (midface retrusion, prominent forehead, nose flattening), and disproportionate extremity length indicate achondroplasia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old nulligravid woman and her 33-year-old husband come to the physician for genetic counseling prior to conception. The husband has had severe psoriasis since adolescence that is now well-controlled under combination treatment with UV light therapy and etanercept. His father and two brothers also have this condition, and the couple wants to know how likely it is that their child will have psoriasis. The inheritance pattern of this patient's illness is most similar to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Like psoriasis, schizophrenia has a multifactorial etiology. Although the exact mutation patterns leading to schizophrenia are unknown, a number of genes have been identified as risk factors for schizophrenia, indicating a polygenic pattern of inheritance. Developmental and environmental factors typically contribute to the onset and severity of polygenically inherited diseases, so traits that follow this inheritance pattern usually exhibit incomplete penetrance or expressive variability. Frequent cannabis use, prenatal infections, and stress during childhood are believed to contribute to the risk of schizophrenia. Other examples of disorders that have a polygenic inheritance pattern include diabetes mellitus, hypertension, androgenic alopecia, cleft palate, and Alzheimer disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Type 1 hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disorder with incomplete penetrance. Only mutations on one gene locus (HFE gene) are responsible for this disorder. In contrast, psoriasis follows a polygenic inheritance pattern, in which more than one gene locus is responsible for expressing the phenotype.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha thalassemia minor is an autosomal recessively inherited disorder. Although several hundred mutations (typically deletions) have been associated with the pathogenesis of alpha thalassemia minor, only mutations within two of the four alleles coding for α-globin contribute to the disorder. In contrast, the expression of psoriasis involves the mutation of many more genes as well as additional environmental factors.

D) INCORRECT:

Alport syndrome is typically inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern, which results in the disease being more severe among males. Digenic inheritance, a form of polygenic inheritance in which there are mutations at two genetic loci, is also possible in the less common autosomally inherited forms of Alport syndrome. However, the polygenic inheritance of psoriasis involves at least 80 genes.

E) INCORRECT:

Oculocutaneous albinism follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern and shows locus heterogeneity, which means that mutations at different genes can result in the same phenotype. In contrast, the expression of the psoriasis phenotype involves the cumulative interaction of mutations at multiple genes as well as additional environmental factors.

F) INCORRECT:

Familial hypercholesterolemia follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and, less commonly, an autosomal recessive pattern. The expression of secondary hypercholesterolemia involves the cumulative interaction of multiple genes and additional environmental factors, as is the case with psoriasis, but familial hypercholesterolemia is caused by single gene defects.
questions.hint: Psoriasis has a multifactorial etiology, which means that both genetic and environmental factors determine the expression of the disease phenotype. Genetic susceptibility to psoriasis is determined by the cumulative interaction of multiple genes (polygenic inheritance).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman and her husband come to the physician for genetic counseling because their first child was born with a meningocele. The baby girl was delivered at term by cesarean section and did not show any other abnormalities. The day after birth, the newborn girl had surgery for her condition. She is now 3 years old and has not had any complications since the procedure. The woman and her husband have no history of medical illness. They have no other children. The couple asks about the risk of a meningocele occurring in their future children. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the recurrence risk of this condition?

choices.text: The risk for their next male child is 50%.
The risk for their next female child is 100%.
The risk for their next child is 25%.
The risk for their next child is correlated with the number of affected relatives.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In X-linked recessive disorders with complete penetrance, the risk for every male offspring is 50% if the mother is the carrier of the mutation. Since the woman is healthy in this case, it is conceivable that she is a carrier; however, a meningocele is not an X-linked recessive disorder. Examples of X-linked recessive disorders with complete penetrance are Duchenne muscular dystrophy and Bruton agammaglobulinemia.
Image Description:

In X-linked recessive inheritance, two copies of the allele located on the X-chromosome should be passed from the parents to the female offspring and only one should be passed to the male offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype (since men are hemizygous for X-linked genes).
