Affected individuals are present not in each generation. Males are affected much more than females who are usually carriers having one copy of the allele. Females can only be affected if they carry two alleles; in such cases, all their sons will be affected, and all their daughters will be carriers. Affected males transmit the allele to all their daughters who thus become carriers, but to none to their sons who receive Y-chromosome.

The overlay indicates the carriers.

B) INCORRECT:

In X-linked dominant disorders with complete penetrance, the risk for every female offspring is 100% if the father is affected by the disorder. A meningocele is not an X-linked dominant condition. Furthermore, in this case, the father is healthy. Examples of X-linked dominant disorders are fragile X syndrome, Alport syndrome, and X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets.
Image Description:

X-linked dominant inheritance, one copy of the allele located on the X-chromosome should be passed from the parents to the offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype. Both males and females can be affected. Affected males usually develop a severe, sometimes nonviable phenotype (as shown in the left half of the image) because they only have one X-chromosome. In an affected male, all the daughters (who receive X-chromosome from their father) but none of the sons (who receive Y-chromosome from their father) will be affected.

C) INCORRECT:

In autosomal recessive disorders with complete penetrance, the risk for every offspring is 25% if both parents are carriers of the mutation. Since both parents are healthy in this case, it is conceivable that they are both carriers; however, a meningocele is not an autosomal recessive disorder. An example of an autosomal recessive disorder with complete penetrance is Friedreich ataxia.
Image Description:

In an autosomal recessive inheritance, two copies of a disease allele (a) located on autosomes are needed to be passed from the parents to the offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype. In this inheritance pattern, affected individuals are present not in every generation. Males and females are equally affected. The parents of an affected individual are usually not affected but carry the causative allele. Autosomal recessive inheritance is common in consanguineous families because of the increased risk of carriage of recessive alleles.

A: healthy allele

D) CORRECT:

Most diseases are multifactorial inheritance disorders (MIDs). The risk of a MID has a positive correlation with the probability of having disease-causing alleles and the probability of exposure to disease-causing environmental factors. For example, individuals with the lowest risk have none of the disease-causing alleles and no exposure to disease-causing environmental factors. A MID's risk generally has a normal distribution and individuals who have a risk above a certain liability threshold will develop the disease. The probability of having disease-causing alleles is in turn positively correlated with the number of relatives with the disease and the disease severity in affected relatives. For these reasons, MIDs often cluster in families or certain population groups. The risk for the next offspring given that one child is already affected (a conditional probability) is higher than the prevalence of the disease in the general population. The probability of having disease-causing alleles correlates negatively with the degree of kinship with the affected relative (e.g., the probability is much lower if a second-degree relative rather than a first-degree relative has the disease).
questions.hint: A meningocele is a type of neural tube defect, which is caused by the interaction of environmental factors (e.g., folate deficiency, maternal diabetes, teratogen exposure) and genetic factors (e.g., mutations in folate metabolism pathways), indicating that it follows a multifactorial inheritance pattern.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman is concerned about her risk for developing breast cancer. Both the mother and an aunt were recently diagnosed with breast cancer and tested positive for a heterozygous mutation in the BRCA1 gene. The patient’s maternal grandmother (age 80) also tested positive for the same heterozygous mutation but has never developed breast cancer.
What is the type of inheritance in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diseases that exhibit anticipation have accelerated, earlier onset or increasing clinical severity with successive generations.

B) INCORRECT:

Variable expressivity refers to phenotypic differences in the degree of presentation of disease. Disease severity may vary from mild to severe in different family members.

C) INCORRECT:

X-linked recessive disorders mostly affect males, and females are generally carriers. Females could manifest the phenotype if homozygous for the mutation, but this would require that both parents are carriers, which is not very likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Autosomal recessive diseases are found in siblings but are unlikely to be found in multiple successive generations.

E) CORRECT:

Autosomal dominant diseases with incomplete penetrance have Mendelian inheritance patterns but may occasionally appear to skip a generation (as in this case). Penetrance refers to the correlation between genotype and phenotype; the disease appears in a variable fraction of patients who carry the mutation.

Key learning point: The probability of developing an autosomal dominant disease when the relevant genetic mutation is present depends on the degree of penetrance of the disease.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is admitted to the intensive care unit after suffering an intracranial hemorrhage. Emergency surgery is performed for decompression purposes, and a ruptured intracranial arteriovenous malformation is discovered and resected.
The mother reports that she had an intracranial arteriovenous malformation embolized years ago, when it was discovered as part of a headache workup. One of her two daughters also has a pulmonary arteriovenous malformation, which manifested with hemoptysis after exercise. There is no other known family history of a vascular disorder.
What is the most likely inheritance pattern underlying this child’s vascular disorder?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sporadic mutations are acquired rather than inherited and are unlikely to be the cause of illness in this family, which has three affected individuals across two different generations.

B) INCORRECT:

In this family, the mother has the inherited vascular disorder, and two of her three children also have it.

C) CORRECT:

The vascular disorder in this family is most likely inherited through an autosomal dominant pattern. In this pattern of inheritance, only a single copy of the aberrant gene is required for the disease to manifest. If one parent has the aberrant gene, each child has a 50% chance of inheriting the disease. In this family, the mother has the inherited vascular disorder, and two of her three children also have it.

Key learning point: When children of both sexes and their mother are affected by a genetic illness, the most likely underlying inheritance pattern is autosomal dominant.

D) INCORRECT:

With an autosomal recessive disorder, two aberrant genes, one from each parent, are required for the disease to manifest. If both parents have the aberrant gene, each child has a 25% chance of inheriting the disease (homozygous), a 50% chance of being a carrier without disease (heterozygous), and a 25% chance of neither being a carrier nor inheriting the disease.

E) INCORRECT:

An X-linked recessive disorder typically occurs only in males and is therefore unlikely in this family, where both males and females are affected.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl presents with her mother concerned about her risk for developing breast cancer. Both the mother and an aunt were recently diagnosed with breast cancer and tested positive for a heterozygous mutation in the BRCA1 gene. The patient’s maternal grandmother (age 80) also tested positive for the same heterozygous mutation but has never developed breast cancer.
What is the type of inheritance in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

X-linked recessive disorders mostly affect males, and females are generally carriers. Females could manifest the phenotype if homozygous for the mutation, but this would require that both parents are carriers, which is not very likely.

B) CORRECT:

Autosomal dominant diseases with incomplete penetrance have Mendelian inheritance patterns but may occasionally appear to skip a generation (as in this case). Penetrance refers to the correlation between genotype and phenotype; the disease appears in a variable fraction of patients who carry the mutation.

Key learning point: The probability of developing an autosomal dominant disease when the relevant genetic mutation is present depends on the degree of penetrance of the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Diseases that exhibit anticipation have accelerated, earlier onset or increasing clinical severity with successive generations.

D) INCORRECT:

Variable expressivity refers to phenotypic differences in the degree of presentation of disease. Disease severity may vary from mild to severe in different family members.

E) INCORRECT:

Autosomal recessive diseases are found in siblings but are unlikely to be found in multiple successive generations.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy with X-linked agammaglobulinemia has been receiving monthly intravenous immunoglobulin infusions since his diagnosis at 18 months of age. His parents ask about their risk of having another child with the same diagnosis. The mother was found to be a carrier of the recessive genetic disorder, and the father is unaffected.
What is the risk that the couple’s next child will be affected with X-linked agammaglobulinemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The likelihood of having another affected child is 25%, not 0%. If the child is a girl, there is no chance that she will have the agammaglobulinemia phenotype, but a 50% chance that she will be a carrier. If the child is a boy, there is a 50% chance that he will be affected.

B) INCORRECT:

The likelihood of having another affected child is 25%, not 50%. If the child is a boy, there is a 50% chance that he will be affected. If the child is a girl, there is no chance that she will have the agammaglobulinemia phenotype, but a 50% chance that she will be a carrier.

C) INCORRECT:

The likelihood of having another affected child is 25%, not 75%. There is a 50% chance that the child will not have the affected gene (XA Y or XA XA) and a 25% chance that the child will be a female carrier (XA Xa). Thus, 75% is the likelihood of having a child with a normal phenotype.

D) INCORRECT:

If this scenario were altered such that the father was affected by agammaglobulinemia (Xa Y) and the mother had wild-type genes, then none of the male offspring would be affected, and all of the female offspring would be carriers, which corresponds to a 100% chance of the female offspring being carriers. However, in the given scenario, the likelihood of having another affected child is 25%.

E) CORRECT:

X-linked agammaglobulinemia is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene, which is located on the X chromosome. Affected patients are either hemizygous males (the mutated gene is on their single X chromosome) or homozygous females (the mutated gene is on both X chromosomes). Heterozygous females (the mutated gene is on one X chromosome) are carriers and typically are unaffected.

In this scenario, the mother is a carrier and has the mutated gene on one X chromosome. The boy's father does not have a BTK gene mutation. The likelihood that their next child will be affected can be determined using a Punnett square (see image below). The lowercase “a” is the mutated gene, and the capital “A” is the wild-type, or unaffected, gene. The likelihood of having another affected child is 25%, demonstrated by the child with genotype Xa Y. Each subsequent child has the same risk of being affected. There is a 50% chance that the child will not have the genotype (XA Y or XA XA) and a 25% chance that the child will be a female carrier (XA Xa). If the child is a boy, there is a 50% chance that he will be affected. If the child is a girl, there is no chance that she will have the agammaglobulinemia phenotype, but a 50% chance that she will be a carrier.

If this scenario were altered such that the father was affected by agammaglobulinemia (Xa Y) and the mother had wild-type genes, then none of the male offspring would be affected, and all of the female offspring would be carriers.

Key learning point: If a woman who is a carrier for an X-linked recessive disorder reproduces with a man who is unaffected by the disorder, the probability that the child will be affected with the disorder is 25%.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old girl is hospitalized for stabilization after clubfoot repair. She is able to sit up independently but does not pull to stand or walk. She can hold a small object and transfer it but does not look for hidden or fallen objects. She makes vowel sounds but not consonant sounds. She is socially engaging and repeats simple gestures. She is not afraid of the examiner.
Her parents report that they have two healthy older children and that there is no significant family history of congenital anomalies or developmental delay.
Which one of the following genetic tests, if any, is the most appropriate initial screening test for this patient?

choices.text: Fluorescence in situ hybridization for the 22q11.2 microdeletion
Trinucleotide repeat analysis for fragile X syndrome

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Clubfoot is a deformation, which means that the foot initially forms correctly but then becomes deformed as a result of external pressures. When clubfoot occurs in isolation, it does not warrant genetic evaluation, as it may be caused entirely by environmental factors that restrict movement, such as multigestation or maternal fibroids. However, when clubfoot is associated with additional findings, such as the pronounced developmental delay in this patient, it can be syndromic and warrants genetic workup. In these cases, clubfoot can be a sign of the syndrome itself (e.g., as in 22q11.2 microdeletion syndrome), or it can be the result of limited fetal movement related to the syndrome.

Many children with congenital anomalies and developmental delay do not fit neatly into a specific syndromic picture, as is the case with this patient. The correct approach to nonspecific symptoms that have a potentially genetic basis (e.g., congenital anomalies, developmental delay, intellectual disability, and autism spectrum disorder) is chromosomal microarray testing to look for chromosomal copy number variants, such as microdeletions and microduplications. Comparative genomic hybridization is now augmented with genome-wide single nucleotide polymorphism analysis, which assesses for regions with absence of heterozygosity, which increase the risk for autosomal recessive disorders.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line genetic test for multiple congenital anomalies, developmental delay, autism spectrum disorder, or intellectual disability is chromosomal microarray testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Conventional karyotype analysis (G banding, metaphase cytogenetics) is insensitive to small deletions and duplications. It is used mainly for the purpose of reproductive counseling, to confirm suspected gross aneuploidy (such as trisomies and monosomies), to look for balanced rearrangements that disrupt critical genes, and to evaluate for the presence of translocation in parental samples where copy-number variation was found on offspring microarray testing to estimate recurrence risk.

C) INCORRECT:

More specific testing, such as single-gene sequencing or specific gene-copy number analysis (e.g., fluorescence in situ hybridization [FISH] or multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification of the 22q11.2 region [the velocardiofacial/DiGeorge syndrome region]), should be used only when the pretest clinical suspicion for the specific syndrome related to that gene is high. Because FISH results can be obtained within 72 hours, FISH analysis is also used when a specific neonatal diagnosis is suspected and prompt results would change the patient’s medical management.

D) INCORRECT:

When clubfoot occurs in isolation, it does not warrant genetic evaluation, as it may be caused entirely by environmental factors that restrict movement, such as multigestation or maternal fibroids. However, when clubfoot is associated with additional findings, such as the pronounced developmental delay in this patient, it can be syndromic and warrants genetic workup.

E) INCORRECT:

Although trinucleotide repeat analysis for fragile X syndrome is recommended for all males with intellectual disability, it is not the appropriate first genetic test in young females with developmental delay.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman and her 28-year-old husband, who are first cousins, have a 2-year-old son with a confirmed autosomal recessive disorder. Genetic testing reveals that both parents carry one mutated allele of the implicated gene. They have no other significant family history or notable findings on physical examination. They are considering having another child and are worried about the possible risk that this child will inherit the same condition.
What is the most likely risk that their next child will have the disorder?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In autosomal recessive disorders, both parents are heterozygous carriers of a mutated allele. Using Mendelian genetics, there is a 25% probability that a child will inherit two mutated alleles, one from each parent, and be affected by the disorder. Each pregnancy is an independent event, and the confirmed carrier status of both parents ensures this risk applies to every conception. Consanguinity increases the likelihood of both parents being carriers, but the inheritance pattern dictates that only 1 in 4 conceptions will be homozygous for the mutant allele.

Key learning point: Autosomal recessive inheritance involves a 25% risk of having an affected child when both parents are carriers, and the risk increases with consanguinity.

B) INCORRECT:

Both parents are confirmed heterozygous carriers, so the risk for an affected child is determined by the Mendelian inheritance pattern for autosomal recessive traits. Consanguinity increases the general risk of congenital anomalies but does not alter the specific 25% risk for an autosomal recessive disorder once carrier status is confirmed.

C) INCORRECT:

A 50% risk is associated with autosomal dominant inheritance, not autosomal recessive. In autosomal recessive inheritance, there is a 25% chance the offspring inherits both mutant alleles and is affected, a 50% chance of being a carrier, and a 25% chance of inheriting two normal alleles. The confirmed carrier status of both parents results in a 25% risk for an affected child.

D) INCORRECT:

In autosomal recessive inheritance, 75% of children will inherit at least one mutated allele, but only 25% will inherit two mutated alleles and be affected. The 75% figure mistakenly includes both carriers and affected individuals, whereas the risk of being homozygous for the mutation is 25%.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to your clinic for genetic counseling prior to conception. For the past year, she has experienced intermittent episodes of headache, nausea, abdominal pain, and tingling in her fingers. She also reports dark urine during these episodes. Her mother and maternal uncle have similar symptoms, while her father is healthy. Her husband is healthy and there is no family history of serious illness on his side. Serum studies show elevated concentrations of porphobilinogen and δ-aminolevulinic acid. Which one of the following is the probability that her child will have the same disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In autosomal recessive conditions, the chance of having an affected child is 25% if both parents are heterozygous carriers of the affected allele (Aa). However, acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant condition. Therefore, inheritance of one affected allele would already cause the disease.

B) INCORRECT:

In autosomal dominant conditions, such as acute intermittent porphyria, the chance of having an affected child is 100% if at least one of the parents is homozygous for the affected allele (AA). This patient must be heterozygous (Aa) for the disease because she is affected, but her father is healthy (aa).

C) CORRECT:

AIP is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in porphobilinogen deaminase. This patient must be heterozygous (Aa) for the disease because she is affected, but her father is healthy (aa). As her husband is phenotypically normal, he cannot be a carrier of a mutated copy of the gene. This woman has a 50% chance of passing on the affected allele, which would cause the disease. Therefore, the risk of having an affected child is ½ or 50%.

See "AD inheritance pattern in heterozygous and homozygous parent” table.

Key learning point: Acute intermittent porphyria is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, giving each child of an affected parent a 50% chance of inheriting the disease.
Image Description:

In autosomal dominant inheritance, only one copy of a disease allele located on autosomes is needed to be passed to cause the expression of the phenotype in an offspring. In this inheritance pattern, there are affected individuals in each generation. Males and females are equally affected. At least one parent of the affected individual carries the disease allele and is affected. Affected males can inherit the phenotype from the affected mother, and affected females can inherit the phenotype from the affected father.

D) INCORRECT:

In autosomal recessive conditions, a phenotypically unaffected child of heterozygous parents (Aa) has an approx. 67% chance of also being an asymptomatic carrier of the affected allele (Aa). In autosomal dominant conditions, such as AIP, every offspring with at least one mutated allele will be affected.

E) INCORRECT:

In autosomal recessive conditions, the chance of having a phenotypically affected child is 0% if one parent is homozygous for the normal allele. Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant condition. Therefore, inheritance of one affected allele would already cause the disease.
questions.hint: This patient has episodes of headaches, abdominal pain, nausea, paresthesias, and dark urine, in the setting of elevated porphobilinogen (PBG) and δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) concentrations. This indicates acute intermittent porphyria (AIP).

questions.text: A 55-year-old construction worker presents for evaluation of a dark lesion on his back that has been changing over the past year. He has a history of multiple blistering sunburns. Examination reveals an 8-mm, asymmetric, irregularly bordered lesion with varying shades of black and brown. The pathogenesis of this condition is most commonly initiated by which of the following molecular events?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intercalation is a process where certain chemicals, known as intercalating agents, insert themselves between the stacked base pairs of DNA. This can distort the DNA structure and lead to frameshift mutations. This mechanism is associated with chemical carcinogens, not the physical energy of UV radiation.

B) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous deamination of cytosine to uracil is a common form of DNA damage that can lead to point mutations if not repaired by base excision repair. While this is a mechanism of mutagenesis, it is not the primary initiating event caused by UV radiation in the development of melanoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Methylation of CpG islands in gene promoter regions is an epigenetic modification that can silence tumor suppressor genes and is involved in the progression of many cancers, including melanoma. However, this is not the initial DNA-damaging event caused by UV radiation; rather, it is a downstream event in carcinogenesis.

D) INCORRECT:

DNA double-strand breaks are a severe form of DNA damage that can lead to chromosomal rearrangements and cancer. However, this type of damage is classically caused by ionizing radiation, such as X-rays and gamma rays, or certain chemotherapeutic agents, not by the non-ionizing ultraviolet radiation primarily responsible for melanoma.

E) CORRECT:

Ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation is absorbed by DNA, leading to the formation of pyrimidine dimers. This occurs when covalent bonds form between adjacent thymine or cytosine bases on the same DNA strand, creating a structural distortion in the DNA helix. If these dimers are not effectively removed by the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway, they can cause mutations during DNA replication. These accumulated mutations in critical genes, such as BRAF or tumor suppressor genes, initiate the malignant transformation of melanocytes.
questions.hint: The clinical features described are classic for malignant melanoma. The patient's extensive sun exposure is the primary risk factor, which causes a specific type of DNA damage.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. At the visit, the mother says that she is worried about the child's vision because of an “eye condition that runs in the family.” She says that the child is doing well in all activities at his preschool, except one in which he is required to sort different colored balls into baskets of a corresponding color. A pedigree chart of the family, with the patient identified by a red arrow, is shown. The most likely cause of these changes in the patient's vision involves which of the following modes of inheritance?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

X-linked dominant inheritance means the allele responsible for the disease is located on the X chromosome and both men and women carrying the X chromosome would be affected. There is a 50% risk of affected mothers passing the altered allele on to their offspring (regardless of sex). Affected fathers pass on the altered allele to all daughters and no sons. Examples include Rett syndrome, Alport syndrome, and hypophosphatemic rickets. Color blindness is not an X-linked dominant disorder.
Image Description:

X-linked dominant inheritance, one copy of the allele located on the X-chromosome should be passed from the parents to the offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype. Both males and females can be affected. Affected males usually develop a severe, sometimes nonviable phenotype (as shown in the left half of the image) because they only have one X-chromosome. In an affected male, all the daughters (who receive X-chromosome from their father) but none of the sons (who receive Y-chromosome from their father) will be affected.

B) INCORRECT:

In mitochondrial inheritance, the disease is caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA and is maternally inherited, as mitochondrial DNA is only passed down from the mother. Any offspring of an affected mother may therefore show signs of the disease. Examples include mitochondrial myopathies (e.g., MELAS syndrome) and exercise intolerance. Color blindness is not a mitochondrial disorder.
Image Description:

Mitochondrial inheritance implies transmission of the disease only through the mother. All the offsprings of affected females may express the phenotype. Variable expression is observed due to heteroplasmy.

C) INCORRECT:

In autosomal recessive inheritance, the disease occurs only if both alleles are altered (homozygosity or compound heterozygosity). Heterozygote carriers of a recessive disease show no phenotypic evidence of the disease. If both parents are heterozygote carriers, the offspring have a 25% probability of inheriting the disease, a 50% probability of becoming a disease carrier, and a 25% probability of being unaffected. Examples include cystic fibrosis, phenylketonuria, and autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease. Color blindness is not an autosomal recessive disorder.
Image Description:

In an autosomal recessive inheritance, two copies of a disease allele (a) located on autosomes are needed to be passed from the parents to the offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype. In this inheritance pattern, affected individuals are present not in every generation. Males and females are equally affected. The parents of an affected individual are usually not affected but carry the causative allele. Autosomal recessive inheritance is common in consanguineous families because of the increased risk of carriage of recessive alleles.

A: healthy allele

D) INCORRECT:

In Y-linked inheritance, the trait is seen in males only and is passed down to all sons of affected males. All daughters of affected men are phenotypically normal and do not have affected offspring. There are no confirmed Y-linked diseases, but inheritance is theoretically possible.

E) CORRECT:

X-linked recessive inheritance occurs in conditions caused by mutated genes found on the X chromosome. Male children, whose only X chromosome carries the altered allele, are always affected by the disease or trait, whereas female children are usually carriers and are only affected if both X chromosomes carry the altered allele. The probability that children of a carrier will inherit the altered X chromosome is 50%, while the probability that a carrier and healthy father will conceive a phenotypically diseased child is 25%.

Examples of X-linked recessive diseases include color blindness (as seen in this patient), hemophilia A/B, G6PD deficiency, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, and Becker muscular dystrophy.
Image Description:

In X-linked recessive inheritance, two copies of the allele located on the X-chromosome should be passed from the parents to the female offspring and only one should be passed to the male offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype (since men are hemizygous for X-linked genes). Affected individuals are present not in each generation. Males are affected much more than females who are usually carriers having one copy of the allele. Females can only be affected if they carry two alleles; in such cases, all their sons will be affected, and all their daughters will be carriers. Affected males transmit the allele to all their daughters who thus become carriers, but to none to their sons who receive Y-chromosome.

The overlay indicates the carriers.

F) INCORRECT:

Autosomal dominant inheritance results in disease even if only one allele is altered and is usually due to mutations in structural genes. If one parent is affected, every child has a 50% risk of inheriting the altered allele and therefore the disease. Examples include autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, achondroplasia, Huntington disease, Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and myotonic dystrophy. Color blindness is not an autosomal dominant disorder.
Image Description:

In autosomal dominant inheritance, only one copy of a disease allele located on autosomes is needed to be passed to cause the expression of the phenotype in an offspring. In this inheritance pattern, there are affected individuals in each generation. Males and females are equally affected. At least one parent of the affected individual carries the disease allele and is affected. Affected males can inherit the phenotype from the affected mother, and affected females can inherit the phenotype from the affected father.
questions.hint: Congenital color perception disorders (especially red-green color vision deficiency) are a well-documented type of inherited vision disorder.

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his adoptive mother for the evaluation of seizures and musty-smelling urine. His immunizations are up-to-date. His height and weight are both below the 10th percentile. He is pale and has blue eyes. He cannot pull himself up from a seated position to stand and does not crawl. Which of the following genetic principles best explains the variety of phenotypic traits seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The term variable expressivity explains why two individuals can have exactly the same mutation on the same chromosome (i.e., same genotype), but show a different degree of disease manifestation and severity (i.e., different phenotype). Although phenylketonuria shows a variable expressivity, this does not explain the diversity of affected organ systems seen in one patient with this condition.

B) CORRECT:

Pleiotropy is the term used when one gene contributes to multiple seemingly unrelated phenotypic effects. This phenomenon explains how a single gene mutation can cause a disease affecting multiple organ systems. Pleiotropy accounts for the phenotypic variations seen in PKU and other diseases such as Marfan syndrome, ataxia telangiectasia, and sickle cell anemia. PKU is caused by a single autosomal recessive mutation in the gene coding for phenylalanine hydroxylase.

Direct measurement of phenylalanine levels is part of the newborn screening for metabolic disorders. If PKU is detected, treatment in terms of lifelong dietary restriction of phenylalanine should be initiated as soon as possible.

C) INCORRECT:

The principle of incomplete penetrance explains why not every individual with a mutant genotype shows the mutant phenotype (e.g., individuals with BRCA mutations), and typically refers to autosomal dominant conditions. Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive disease that manifests in all individuals carrying mutations on both PKU alleles. This complete penetrance can be reduced by a lifelong phenylalanine-restricted diet, though. However, the degree of penetrance is unrelated to the diversity of affected organ systems seen in a patient with PKU.

D) INCORRECT:

Anticipation refers to a pattern of inheritance in which the succeeding generation develops a disease with greater severity or at a younger age than the ones before (e.g., Huntington disease, fragile X syndrome). This phenomenon is usually attributed to the gradual expansion of a trinucleotide repeat polymorphism within or near a coding gene. Phenylketonuria is not a trinucleotide repeat disorder but inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

E) INCORRECT:

Loss of heterozygosity describes an event in a cell in which one allele of a gene is dysfunctional due to an inherited mutation, and the remaining allele is later switched off via an acquired mutation. If this mutation takes place in a tumor suppressor gene, cancer might develop. This phenomenon, called the two-hit hypothesis, is classically seen in retinoblastoma or Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Phenylketonuria, however, is an autosomal recessive disease caused by an inherited mutation of both PKU alleles.
questions.hint: This infant's constellation of developmental delay, seizures, pale skin, blue eyes, and musty odor are consistent with the diagnosis of phenylketonuria (PKU).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician with intermenstrual bleeding and heavy menses for the past 4 months. She does not take any medications. Her father died of colon cancer at the age of 42 years. A curettage sample shows dysplastic tall, columnar, cells in the endometrium without intervening stroma. Germline sequencing shows a mutation in the MLH1 gene. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of neoplasia in this patient?

choices.text: Inability to excise bulky DNA adducts
Instability of short tandem DNA repeats
Impaired repair of deaminated DNA bases

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The accumulation of double-stranded DNA breaks is associated with BRCA+ breast cancers and Fanconi anemia (due to defects in homologous end joining) as well as ataxia telangiectasia (due to defects in nonhomologous end joining). These defects are not associated with endometrial cancer, familial colorectal cancer, or the MLH1 gene.

B) INCORRECT:

Defective checkpoint control is associated with mutations in the p53 tumor suppressor gene and leads to unrestrained division of cells. This is the underlying defect of Li-Fraumeni syndrome, a familial cancer syndrome associated with sarcoma, breast carcinoma, leukemia, and adrenocortical carcinoma. This condition is not associated with endometrial cancer, familial colorectal cancer, or the MLH1 gene.

C) INCORRECT:

The inability to excise bulky DNA adducts is the key defect in nucleotide excision repair. This is the underlying defect of xeroderma pigmentosum, a condition in which cells cannot repair the pyrimidine dimers that form after ultraviolet light exposure. Xeroderma pigmentosum manifests with dry skin, photosensitivity, and early skin cancers. This condition is not associated with endometrial cancer, familial colorectal cancer, or the MLH1 gene.

D) CORRECT:

Lynch syndrome is associated with instability of short tandem DNA repeats (microsatellites) due to germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2, and MSH6). Patients with Lynch syndrome have an increased lifetime risk for multiple malignancies including colorectal, endometrial, gastric, urothelial, and ovarian cancers.

E) INCORRECT:

Base excision repair replaces deaminated DNA bases throughout the cell cycle. Defects in base excision repair are associated with some forms of familial colorectal cancer but are not associated with endometrial cancer or the MLH1 gene.
questions.hint: The features of intermenstrual bleeding, heavy menses, and histopathologic dysplasia of the endometrium suggest a diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma. In a young woman with a family history of colorectal cancer at a young age, these features raise suspicion for a hereditary cancer syndrome. The presence of a mutated MLH1 gene confirms a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome.
